children.subject: True. But a GPA cap is put in place, everyone will study harder, so the average score will go up. So in effect the difficulty does increase.
They have grading bins in lower divs and they tell us that if everyone does well everyone can get an A (not that it happens, but others doing well does not adversely affect you)

@previouscomment while there are grading bins in 61A and B, it's been shown that professors still control grade distributions by adjusting the difficulty of exams. From my experience at least in 61B last semester, based on point distributions before the final shown in glookup, a much larger percentage were on track to get an A- or an A than previous years. However the final for that class was significantly harder than previous years. Hug himself even apologized for the difficulty of the exam beforehand which implies he was fully aware students would receive lower scores than they normally would on his finals. Most likely to balance out grade distributions. I'm not saying Hug is evil for doing that, as stated in another comment teachers genuinely want us to succeed, but while theoretically everyone can get an A with grading bins, the school will make every effort that not everyone can.
The difficulty of the lower division exams has not increased noticeably.
Berkeley CS is the best in the US

I think that you bring up a lot of good points. Personally, I think the issue here is something more than just the difficulty of those lower div CS classes. Its an issue with over enrollment and just how the declaration system works. As far as I know, we are the only UC with an LSCS program and when people are admitted to the college of letters and science, they are not being judged for their major. This means a prospective history, English, computer science major etc are ranked against each other regardless of intended major and with a large number of students intended CS, with the current system, there is no way to distinguish between them. I've heard that the average EECS admitted student ranks higher than an average engineering admitted students and I would think the same applies for LSCS intended compared to other majors in letter and science. And with 61A last year being larger than some whole departments on campus, there is a serious issue in our system and because of the budgeting crisis, we admitting nearly 2000 new freshman next year, many of whom I suspect will also be LSCS intended. I wouldn't be surprised if enrollment in 61A goes past 2000. Once solution would be to dissolve the CS major in letter and science and join in into the college of engineering as another major and admit directly when applying rather than declaring, but I doubt that will happen. The other option is to make the courses harder. This isn't the greatest option, but given the position that the university is in, its the path of least resistance, given the budgeting crisis and overal campus issues. I think the points that you bring up are definitely some that people should think about when deciding where to go. The reason I say all of this is to try and think about the larger picture and what is going on at a university level. Professor Hug, Denero, Rao and other don't take joy is watching students get wrecked on midterms and finals, they want their students to learn, but are put in an unfortunate situation because of what's going on at a university level. And I don't think this is something that can be changed with funding. We are a university supporting all fields of research and thinking, and having half (exaggeration) the university dedicated to CS or EECS is not the ideal. Hope that helps

What I have found thus far, is that CS at Berkeley goes far beyond simply the educational experience in terms of being lectured and digesting the material. I'll defer to those who have stated this before, but when youre studying CS here (and EE too), you really are surrounded by some extremely bright students and tier top faculty. For some, that climate alone makes it worth it. Others probably have their own reasons, I know a couple friends of mine were attracted by the idea that Berkeley has a reputation in academic rigor (i.e. being challenged extensively). And I have my own reasons for wanting to study EECS here. Would you and I, and many others have an easier time at a CSU or another UC in terms of workload/stress? Definitely. I have no issues making that statement, not only from my experience, but Sahai has made some very good points about this, and not only regarding UCs, but other schools as well.

So to the point about "worth it", I think that depends on one's expectation. If you only seek to become a programmer and work on personal projects, perhaps your experience here will be slightly negative. If one embraces the notion (and im not preaching here) that Berkeley aims to teach computer science to the fullest extent, then the experience is the opposite. Though, I don't think this is to say that Berkeley does not produce software engineers or developers, because thats obviously not true.
3.0. I got rekt in Math54 of all classes smh
Grades in CS upper divs help with declaring if I don't get the necessary GPA after taking 61A,B, and 70?
nope that's only with the old gpa cap (ie befote 2015)

Congratulations on making it this far! I will say I felt the exact same disillusionment (missed the GPA cap by .03 initially, got an A in an upper div, still made it in) after taking and hating 61C/70. However, I will say, I've really like every upper div I've taken (100/161/186/188) and feel like they're very useful in my development. 

One thing to note! The CS grading guidelines for upper div's are more lenient, new this semester with a suggested average between 3.0 and 3.5. That breaks down to 45% As, 40% Bs, 10% Cs, and 5% D/Fs. That and I've noticed the material seems to either be easier or more rewarding in upper div's, so persevere -- you'll find a different CS experience on the other side of declaring!

I have a serious problem with this mentality. Your entire purpose, the reason you have a 6-figure-base salary, should be to help and improve the lives of the people around you who are struggling. 

The greatest validation of studying and mastering CS, then, would be knowing you're in a position to do so.

I didn't say anything about not to"help and improve the lives of the people around you who are struggling." or whatsoever.

Instead, I was emphasizing the contrast between CS and mostly non-CS in the real market is huge enough to justify the effort spending in these heavy-loaded Berkeley CS courses.

Besides, I decide what my purpose should be.

Although I don't have a crystal clear purpose at this moment, but claiming moral high ground, be condescending and judgmental to students with different views would definitely not be my purpose.
By the end of the day, you will realize that it's totally worth it with 6-figure-base salary offers in your hand and watching others struggling for their lives.

I am OP. Thanks so much to those giving me your thought and answer. 

If you gave me your answer to my initial question based on your experience in upper division course, I appreciate it and felt a bit better by knowing that GPA average will be less stressful in Upper Division, and many upper div classes are more practical. I am taking CS169 this summer and hated the fact I am taking it and about to change it, but I am now not so unhappy to wait to see how it will goes... 

If you shared your thought about what I have felt about this CS stuffs, I am thankful for being educated with some new perspectives or perspectives I didn't think so important. I hated prof from 61A, B and 70 from the bottom of my heart when I was taking and after taking, but yeah you are true. They are in the position and have to do so, and hopefully not  having fun seeing students struggling... And those stories about CS cap and demands, yeah it is like democracy, maybe not the best way of doing all these things, probably really bad, but better than other worse ways of doing so. 

Personally I still feel I am paying all the money for top students/profs doing research and instead I am receiving the reputation, but will see how I will be feeling at the end of graduation. And I don't think I will be solely perfectly satisfied with receiving 6-figure based salary but it never be a bad thing and appreciate someone brought it up. 

Thanks again. Have a good summer...

I'd say that I've talked to professors who tell me that the GPA cap is near universally despised by the faculty. They have limited resources but the university doesn't let them say "We can only take 1000 L&S students for the CS major", this is literally the only allowed way to limit the number of students who get in. So yeah, it's pretty crappy, but they don't have much choice.

I'd also echo what others have said about upper divs. I took 186 this last semester and the final three (I think?) weeks of lectures were guest lecturers from industry. And let me tell you, hearing how Amazon implemented their database and why from one of the guys who did it is a pretty amazing experience that you don't get at many other places.

history.content:
All I say here is said with no malice. I am writing this with a friend of mine who have taken CS courses together.

I believe there are so many people who could have declared CS if they tried it before 2016 but are struggling more or even failing, in my opinion, maybe because of the raise of hardness in 61A & 61B's exams (and students are doing very well so the average score of exams are maintained as high as previous years). Resulting mental stress and workload were more than something I can just simply describe "hard". (this is my opinion from the experience that I always mark around 80-85% on past exams when I do it for practice but got like 65-70% on this years exam. And the hardness of exam is not a huge focus of my discussion)

I have completed 61A, 61B, and 70, and now I have a safe GPA to declare CS. However, I strongly doubt if the time, energy, health, social life I dedicated/gave up for these CS courses were ever worth than side projects/research/interview practice that I could have possibly done instead using the time. I feel like I am now just good at handling 61A and 61B stuffs. I can teach people how to succeed in 61B, I can give people a book of tips for exams of these classes. But have no idea of how to succeed in real world. 

I have many friends who went San Jose State or other UCs (even though some of them were admitted to UC Berkeley), and they are/were casually enjoying their CS classes and also work on projects and researches and get very naturally prepared for real world job during the semester in terms of practical knowledge and also regume. They do not necessarily have a higher GPA than me but they all know more frame works, more languages more in depth, have done so many job interviews practice.  

How about me? I have 3.3G-3.5PA for CSs and lower GPA for other courses that I gave up getting good grade for the 3 other requirement courses, and absolutely no side project or any practical knowledge. I have just started practicing interviewing. I am of course working on a project right now and find it like trillion times funner, educational, interesting than any of there three courses. 

I know some of you guys just will tell me "why didn't you work on side project during semester then?". I just couldn't, I tried multiple times and had to stop, because of the fear of my failing to declare. Some may say to me "you are learning CS, not programming, you are wrong place". Maybe you are very correct, but I honestly don't know. I want to figure out that in the near future... 

My simple question is, is it worth? is CS at UC Berkeley worth than its reputation? Is this mental struggle will continue till the end of graduation? Will I be prepared for real world? Should I just do easier major and learn everything by myself (as I just did in 61A, 61B, 70? You know these are pretty much self taught classes... Am I overly wrong...?)

Thank you for reading... Kindly tell me what you think about this. If I am talking like a sh*t, please help me realize something valuable I failed to see... You can give me preaching I will gratefully listen...

I feel like I am now just good at handling 61A and 61B stuffs. I can teach people how to succeed in 61B, I can give people a book of tips for exams of these classes. But have no idea of how to succeed in real world. 

I have many friends who went San Jose State or other UCs (even though some of them were admitted to UC Berkeley), and they are/were casually enjoying their CS classes and also work on projects and researches and get very naturally prepared for real world job during the semester in terms of practical knowledge and also regume. They do not necessarily have a higher GPA than me but they all know more frame works, more languages more in depth, have done so many job interviews practice.  

How about me? I have 3.3G-3.5PA for CSs and lower GPA for other courses that I gave up getting good grade for the 3 other requirement courses, and absolutely no side project or any practical knowledge. I have just started practicing interviewing. I am of course working on a project right now and find it like trillion times funner, educational, interesting than any of there three courses. 

I know some of you guys just will tell me "why didn't you work on side project during semester then?". I just couldn't, I tried multiple times and had to stop, because of the fear of my failing to declare. Some may say to me "you are learning CS, not programming, you are wrong place". Maybe you are very correct, but I honestly don't know. I want to figure out that in the near future... 

My simple question is, is it worth? is CS at UC Berkeley worth than its reputation? Is this mental struggle will continue till the end of graduation? Will I be prepared for real world? Should I just do easier major and learn everything by myself (as I just did in 61A, 61B, 70? You know these are pretty much self taught classes... Am I overly wrong...?)

Thank you for reading... Kindly tell me what you think about this. If I am talking like a sh*t, please help me realize something valuable I failed to see... You can give me preaching I will gratefully listen...
